awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Processing garden paths across dialects: A study of African American English
awd_abstract_narration:
The United States is home to a large multi-cultural and multi-lingual population. Many speakers interact with different languages and different varieties of English daily. A lot of research has been devoted to understanding how speakers of multiple languages, multilinguals, use their knowledge of multiple languages to interpret language in context. But less is known about how speakers who know different varieties of a single language ('dialects') accomplish this. In this dissertation project, the researchers investigate African American Language (AAL), a variety of English spoken primarily, but not exclusively, by African Americans. The research investigates how speakers of AAL understand sentences that use linguistic features that are present in AAL but not present in Mainstream American English (MAE), the 'standard' dialect spoken across the US. AAL and MAE overlap significantly, but there are specific grammatical constructions where the two diverge. This project investigates when and how AAL speakers use these dialect-specific constructions in different contexts. Research into how AAL speakers use context to do this will shed light onto how language processing proceeds in more naturalistic contexts, and will also shed light into the usage of a variety of English spoken by a significant portion of the United States' population.

The comprehension of ambiguous sentences has been a central component of psycholinguistic research for many decades. The classic demonstration of this is the 'garden path effect', the finding that comprehenders encounter processing difficulty when ambiguous sentences are disambiguated towards an unlikely syntactic structure. This happens because comprehenders make active predictions about what syntactic continuations are likely as they process linguistic input, with difficulty occurring when those predictions turn out to be incorrect. The predictions comprehenders make can be influenced by a variety of factors, such as word frequency, plausibility, grammatical knowledge, and even social features of the speaker. The current study uses garden path effects as a window into what syntactic expectations AAL speakers have during language processing. Specifically, this project employs visual-world eye-tracking to investigate how these speakers use factors such as speaker voice and the presence of other dialect-specific grammatical features to adjust their predictions about how a sentence is structured. The specific structure to be investigated is the phenomenon of contact subject relative clauses. In AAL, it is possible to have sentence such as "Sally is the one (who) sent a letter to her mom" where the "who" is optional. In MAE, in contrast, "who" is required. By investigating whether AAL speakers interpret Sally as the sender of the letter or receiver of the letter in a sentence like this, the researchers will be able to measure how much speakers anticipate this construction in different contexts. This research will help add to growing literature on how contextual factors (e.g., speaker voice) influence on-going linguistic processing as well as adding critical diversity to the psycholinguistic literature.

por.por_cntn:
The United States boasts great linguistic diversity: There are a great many languages and language varieties spoken by Americans. In this project, the researchers were interested to learn more about how variation between closely related language varieties influenced language comprehension. The question the researchers wanted to understand better was how easily language users were able to comprehend language structures that were not in their native language variety, but existed in closely related varieties that exist in the wider American speech community.The researchers in this project investigated this question for both human language users, as well as artificial language models (AI). 


To this end, the researchers investigated language comprehension in two groups of speakers: an African American Language (AAL) speaking population, and a Mainstream American English (MAE) population. AAL and MAE are two language varieties that are widely spoken throughout the USA. While they share many similarities in terms of sounds, structure, and vocabulary, they diverge in crucial ways. This project focused on one particular syntactic structure as a way of addressing the larger research question: The way in which these two varieties differ in their relative clauses. In particular, AAL often allows subject contact relative clauses: For example in many varieties of AAL, it would be grammatical to say “He was the one sent the boxes to Lena” while in MAE it is typically obligatory to include a relative pronoun or complementizer ('that') in this context: “He was the one that sent the boxes to Lena.” This syntactic difference between the varieties can create situations where a sentence is ambiguous in one variety, but not another. The researchers in this project looked at such ambiguities, and asked how different groups of speakers resolved these ambiguities as a function of their different linguistic backgrounds, and as a function of the perceived background of the speaker.


The researchers collected psycholinguistic data in the form of a speeded comprehension task to measure how such structures are processed by speakers of different speech communities, carried out linguistic fieldwork with an AAL speaking community to understand how subject contact relatives can be used in AAL, and explored how well large language models are able to understand these syntactic differences across varieties. These activities contributed to a deeper understanding of how subject contact relatives operate in AAL, and provided critical computational and psycholinguistic data from AAL - a critically under-investigated language variety. The psycholinguistic data provided a picture of how a language user might process syntactic structures that are not present in their variety, but are closer/similar to other structures that are. The results did not suggest that processing these configurations varied as a function of the perceived background of the speaker. However, the researchers did see differences in how the different language groups processed subject contact relatives: Speakers processed these structures in a way that was consistent with their own language variety’s grammar, even when it meant assigning a syntactic structure to the input that is known from other psycholinguistic research to be difficult for language users. In addition, the fieldwork data suggested that there is homogeneity across the AAL speaker community in how subject contact relatives are treated. While speakers in this community could have varied in their usage of these structures and still been able to communicate, the results suggested that the speakers of this community share systematic and homogenous judgments about what’s possible in the variety, despite this ambiguity.


These findings have broader implications by shedding light on how language users and artificial language models process language that may not conform to their expectations. Through her dissertation research, the co-PI developed diverse methodologies that can be used to further probe these critical questions, for both humans and machines. Given the linguistic diversity of the USA, this is a critical question, and further understanding how linguistic differences impact downstream language comprehension will be of increased importance with the increased connectivity across the nation afforded by the internet, and the increasing importance of centralized, large language models in the growing field of AI.
